job_title: Engineer
pros:
If you have no imagination, and are content with mediocrity and silence then this company will be perfect for you. If you value competence you won't find much of it. If you value career growth then you had better know the right people.
The hours are good, and there is (usually) plenty of flexibility for doctor's appointments and the like.
cons:
Orwellian Nightmare combined with Kafkaesque bureaucracy, incompetence abounds. 
Promotion is not based on merit whatsoever.
It is almost impossible to get fired, unless blatant time card fraud is involve - unless you refuse to tow the line politically and then you are never heard from again. Every single year the company makes a change to help their bottom line at the employees expense. The "benefits" aren't very good anymore. There is no sick-leave, and the pitiful "paid time off" benefit must be used for illness. Anyone that takes a day off when very ill will never be able to save vacation time.

job_title: Business Management Analyst in Linthicum Heights, MD
pros:
Great introduction to Earned Value Management as well as government proposal, contracting and reporting protocols.
Potential to break into other functions within the company (such as Pricing, BD, Operations Management, etc.)
Extended Work Week compensation.
cons:
Work scope seems to increase year over year, seemingly fulfilling financial requirements of some other functional groups. 

On large programs at least, most time is spent synthesizing data with a very short window for analyzing and troubleshooting.

Business Management / Program Control Analyst work is quite repetitive and can get mundane very quickly.

Upward mobility from lower levels is not guaranteed due to current promotion procedures. 

ERP Systems and reporting technology could be better integrated. 

Compensation is not very competitive. Additionally, external hires with less experience are seemingly compensated more which isn't great for morale.

review_title: Fill a seat till something better comes along.
job_title: Front End Developer in Aurora, CO
pros: They don't let you go and will find work for you if a contract is over.
cons:
You're just a body in a seat for a contract really. Your skill set doesn't really matter a lot and sometimes you can just get moved onto a task/contract doing something completely unrelated to what you do. 

You're forced to compete with your co-workers for raises. They allot a certain number of slots per branch for the Top Performers, Great Performers, or Successful Performers. So no matter how good you did, if the Top Performers allotment is filled by high profile contract members then you don't get the best raise. 

You get lost in the noise. Often it feels like no one knows who you are or what you do primarily because you get shuffled around onto tasks where you don't get to use your skillset effectively. If you don't get shuffled onto a high profile contract then no one really knows who you are.

You work on a lot of abandonware. A lot of tasks just go until funding gets cut in the middle of the project and you don't get to finish it. Having project after project after project end without being finished can be very demotivating and adds to the above problem of no one knowing who you are because no project you work on sees the light of day.

review_title: My Experience:  Not Great So Far
job_title: Engineering
pros:
Interview

- Felt great after my interview with the team, manager, and recruiter.
- Was confident that it went well and received the job offer a few days later.
- Received decent compensation and relocation package in my offer letter, although it was non negotiable.

Background Checks
- Overall, this went very smoothly.
- Onboarding Specialist was great in replying back whenever I had questions regarding my background check and documentation needed for orientation.

Benefits

- 9/80 Schedule (Every other Friday off)
- 401K (Can choose either Traditional, Roth, or After Tax)
- Dental 
- Vision
- Free EAP counseling (short-term) up to 8 sessions/year through Beacon Health

Resources

- EAP are great resources to speak to whenever you feel down because of your job, especially during the pandemic.
- Employees outside of the team and/or unrelated to the project I’m working on seem very nice/intelligent people.
cons:
Onboarding Process

- There is little to no onboarding process at NG. Certainly, after completing my background check and other required documentation, everything went downhill. I’m going to explain exactly what happened from my experience so far:
 - Before orientation, I never received a protocol from either HR or my manager, as to where I needed to report to on my first day for orientation. Since I relocated and stayed in temporary housing, I assumed that either HR or my manager would email me directions and time to arrive at the facility.
 - After my first day, IT setup my laptop/computer/equipment, however, one of the IT support reps misplaced them somewhere most likely in the wrong cubicle (have absolutely no idea how that happened). As a result, I received them a few days later (unbelievable).
 - For the first couple weeks, I did the new employee tasks, but on top of that, I was expected to do tons of reading documentation that was difficult for me to absorb. Basically, one day, my manager came over to my cubicle to check up on me. My manager looked to see what I was reading to ensure I was reading the right material. They wanted to see if they could make it any easier for me. Based on the conversation, he could not make it any easier for me, as I started to become very stressed and burnt out. Juggling new employee tasks while reading a crazy load of documentation is unrealistic to absorb in a short amount of time.
 - Next, I went through some training for a system (not familiar with), but did not know it needed to be installed on my computer, as I was not told ahead of time. If anything, my manager even admitted that it was their fault. Because of this, I was very behind with the training and couldn’t even catch up to the other employees to learn and do the exercises during the class. As soon as I got it installed on my computer, I went through the exercises all on my own with ZERO help, as everyone was “too busy” to help out.
 - My actual first assignment/task did not occur until a few months later from my start date. The worse part was I got invited to a meeting that was not only short notice, but was assigned to only do my tasks with no training, guidance, coaching, and help and unrelated to what I learned from the training. 

On The Job Training

- There is little to no on the job training.
- Seems to be that the expectation is to learn everything on your own. 
- That really loses not only my motivation to work, but also don’t look forward to go to work. 
- I believe it has to do with the work not being interesting for me, as I already feel stressed and burnt out each and every day.

Benefits

- Does not provide sick days. Have to use PTO for sick days.
- Medical is very expensive per paycheck.

Resources

- My manager has no interest in assisting me as an employee. They only care about deadlines and customer satisfaction. Nothing else matters to them. 
- The team/coworkers involved in projects I am doing are not very friendly and are unwilling to help get me up to speed. 
- HR is not the best resource to go to for career opportunities. They referred me to talk to my manager, which isn’t a great option either.

Overall

- Hope this gets better soon since it’s been only a few months being employed at NG.
- Would be very open to even possibly transferring to a different job at NG.

review_title: Decent place to start, but need to be very self motivated
job_title: Systems Engineer in Baltimore, MD
pros:
Great work life balance - flexing my hours has been very useful, especially given personal circumstances. Management varies, however.

High Salary - bonuses every year and substantial pay raise with promotions.

Growth opportunities - many levels to engineering. Lateral moves are also not uncommon. 

Paid Masters - education tuition reimbursement 

Positive attitude towards education and gaining skills - getting training is often welcomed and encouraged for sharpening and gaining new skills.

Discounts - get discounts at other companies like lenovo, Dell, Samsung, Apple, and many more. Not that impressive as Amazon has better deals and it doesn't drop the price that much. Just an added perk.

Lots of great things about the company. Work-life balance is by far the greatest. Working remotely, flex hours, and 9/80 fridays are a huge benefit.
cons:
Lots of slow days - some days will be fast paced due to deadlines, however there are many slow days. As a high performer, this becomes discouraging and depressing. I almost always have to ask for work; sometimes I charge time for no work being done

Less work for young employees - a lot of time, we're given menial work as younger engineers. It felt as though I didn't do much and I got a promotion, which felt weird. It seems like this was more of an attempt to keep me working for the company to combat their high attrition rate.

Quality of workplace highly dependent on location - I work as a Pathways engineer. You get 3 rotations before deciding where you'd like to station yourself. My first rotation as a systems engineer was more of a secretary, as I managed file organization, offered tech support, and supported/maintained a completed engineering project. At my next rotation, I worked on data analysis and coding. Same title, wildly different responsibilities.

Passive aggressive management - applies to above point; depends on location.

Lack of transparency upon entering Northrop Grumman as an employee

Mixed bag of employees - most are welcoming and friendly, however I have met quite a few who are prejudiced and judgemental. It has made me question my place in the company and industry as a whole.

Paid Time Off (PTO): no sick days, but get paid time off, about 13 work days starting out (~100hrs). You can go negative if you're sick, but that means as you earn PTO hours, you're basically paying back a PTO debt. During covid-19, PTO can drop to -80 hours and then future accumulated PTO pays off this negative balance over time.

Unstable industry - funding can turn off and then management scrambles to find you work. It can be very irritating having worked on something for a long time and then get interrupted for months at a time until program funding is available again. Recently, NG lost a contract and some people are looking for new jobs within NG.

I have had mostly poor experiences here, and perhaps I feel disgruntled in writing this review. There is a reason NG has a high attrition rate, especially with younger engineers, so maybe then this review is justified. My coworkers and I occasionally vent to each other about how we are not very happy with how work is going. I'm one person, so make sure to read other reviews and take this with a grain of salt. 

This could be a great fit for you, but just not for me. I don't do well in slow paced environments and need to feel responsible for more work than simple tasks. Understandably, junior engineers need a learning mindset and patience, but it seems ridiculous to me how little work I have for the salary I'm paid.

Where do I start.....

- Extremely difficult to get promoted internally, many leave in order to get paid their worth. If not they'll continue to get pats on the back while being over worked.

- Was rated an excellent performer for multiple years and was praised constantly by management for working on tasks that were way above my pay grade but when it came time to talk about being promoted to that pay grade I was given the run around. 

-Tuition Reimbursement (which was a huge selling point in the recruitment process) was cut from unlimited to any school to 10K without any warning. Leaving employees who started their Masters/PHD programs with the peace of mind that they would be covered now scrambling to figure out how they're going to afford it all. When we complained to HR we were told to take out a loan or only take one class a year. This hurt the morale of the early career-mid career talent pool as many of us left other offers on the table because of this benefit just to get the rug pulled from underneath us once we got here.

-Beware of the people that got their job because their relative has a friend in high places as they'll be getting paid more than you with no experience what so ever. They'll come in with signing bonuses and perks they'd never give you as you're training them and holding their hand constantly because they don't know what they're doing. Perfect example, I had a role where I asked for a telework day since I lived pretty far and I was immediately denied and given the run around. A new employee joined our team a week later and had two telework days. I eventually called out my manager's hypocrisy as I was outperforming the new employee while commuting from another state while the new employee was local and I was granted a grand prize of 1 telework day (gee thanks, smh). If you're someone unwilling to pushback on things they will continue to push your limits to see how far it can go.

-Applying to jobs internally is a joke, you have to know someone in order to get any role even if you're over qualified for the position. You won't even get the courtesy of a "thank you for applying but we decided to pick someone else" it's like you threw your application in a dark hole. 

-HR stinks, I brought a friend of mine to an on the spot hiring event with multiple clearances under their belt and they didn't have any hiring managers in my friend's discipline even though they put that they were looking for his discipline on all of the flyers and I had an HR rep tell me directly that 2-3 managers in that discipline would be there. My friend drove 2hrs for that complete waste of time.

-I can keep going but I'll leave the rest for your imagination.

review_title: Exciting projects found within a monstrosity of a company
job_title: Systems Engineer in Redondo Beach, CA
pros:
Work on some of the largest and most advanced defense contracts the DoD has awarded
Very flexible work schedule
9/80 schedule, i.e. every other Friday off is usually the "norm". Expect to work some off-Fridays though.
Vacation accrual, i.e. rollover hours between calendar years up to generous maximums
Paid overtime when working extra hours (has to be authorized, but that's usually pretty easy. Just 1x pay though, no time-and-a-half or anything)
Loss of contracts or proposal does not mean you will get laid off. The company does a great job of finding employees other work when projects close out.
Overall very friendly co-workers and some brilliant minds
One of the most demographically diverse environments I've ever worked, especially considering the engineering industry
Management is experienced and usually keeps the employee insulated from managerial nuisances
They will pay for your education with generous applications of "the rules" in your favor. I have never taken advantage myself, but I've heard so many great things about the "EdAssist" program I have to mention it.
cons:
Fairly average pay and benefits, nothing special. 401k match maxes out at 7% for new employees, if you contribute 8%.
Bonuses are only for top performers, based on your management performance review. They limit the recipients to ~10% at each level, so if you're new and below level 4 - good luck. Even if you get one, the amount is so small you don't even care to try the next year. I've seen about 3% of my gross salary one year when I was awarded the "top" level of review. Don't expect anything beyond your base salary.
Absolutely no company-sponsored extras, i.e. no work-related parties, no freebies, no perks, not even break rooms or TVs in their so-called flagship campus "Space Park" in Redondo Beach. This campus is a historical wonder, but a modern-day joke for such a large company to still be working in.
Enormous corporation (80,000+ employees) means you cannot even begin to understand the high-level management structure. You will see congratulatory emails about VIP-level promotions for people you have not only never heard of, but couldn't even figure out their role if you tried.
Almost all of NG's business is from government contracts, most of which are defense related and a large portion of those classified SCI (the biggest exception is probably James Webb Space Telescope) This means lots of overhead, red-tape and process bloat. Be prepared for a one-line software code change to take 6 months and cost $1 million. SIGH.
Business travel can be frequent, depending on your project. The business travel rules are nuts and an absolute nightmare to work though since you have to adhere to the government FAR regulations. Booking a short domestic trip can be way more trouble than necessary, especially when submitting expenses on the return.
